Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Novel approach in developing sustainable polymer composites
Award.AbstractNarration:
Currently, several aspects are missing in the current polymer or polymer composites based products. The first one is mechanical strength, which can be potentially improved by nanofillers. The second one is durability. The third one is sustainability, as replacing oil based polymers with sustainable filler produced from wood can reduce the need of using oil based products. This proposal aims at developing a new generation of high performance polymer composites with properties superior to the already existing solutions. It is going to create a very exciting opportunity of having the new generation of high performance sustainable nanofillers produced in substantial quantities.

Addressing the challenges related to traditional nanofillers while maintaining structural integrity of nanocomposites can be achieved by using sustainable bio-based nanofillers, such as surface modified Nano-Crystalline Cellulose (NCC). A development, optimization and commercializing of a novel process of making such materials is the basis of this proposal. Using nanocellulose as filler can be a very promising and scalable method of producing inexpensive 'green' composites. The proposed technology can be also very cost-efficient solution, given that USDA projections point out an extraordinary opportunity for this filler as nanocrystalline cellulose applications are expected to reach $600 billion mark by 2020 in the US alone.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project has focused on exploring commercial potential of new approach for creating novel polymer based materials. The use of nanomaterials is revolutionizing the properties of the existing composites, such as improved stiffness, weight reduction, and better durability. However, many nanomaterials are either not sustainable or toxic. Our approach is to manufacture new polymer composites based on such sustainable nanomaterial as wood derived nanocellulose. This strategy can benefit many industries, ranging from aerospace to food packaging. More specifically the investigator and his student have conducted prototyping and commercialization activities to realize a full potential of this approach. Moreover, several hypotheses related to the most promising materials’ properties, approaches to materials’ design, intellectual property protection and current industrial/customer needs were tested in the duration of this project. This project provided graduate student with very valuable skills for transitioning from an academic research to industrial research and development sector. The intellectual merit of this project is in developing a new technology to produce the new generation of materials with properties superior to the existing one. The broader impacts are in utilizing sustainable, non-toxic environmentally friendly materials to address the current needs of our society to use more energy efficient and better performing materials. These advances can result in improvements of our well being and in accelerating our economic growth.
